Example

Impose the derivative boundary conditions on this solution:

Solution

\(\qquad \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial x}=(-\lambda A \sin \lambda x +\lambda B\cos \lambda x)(Ce^{\lambda y}+D e^{-\lambda y})\)


Hence\(\dfrac{\partial u}{\partial x}(0, y) = 0\) gives \(\lambda B(Ce^{\lambda y}+D e^{-\lambda y}) = 0\) for all \(y.\)
The possibility \(\lambda = 0\) can be excluded this would give a trivial constant solution in \((4)\). Hence we must choose \(B = 0\).
The condition \(\dfrac{\partial u}{\partial x}(1, y) = 0\) gives

\(\qquad -\lambda A\sin\lambda(Ce^{\lambda y}+D e^{-\lambda y}) = 0\)

Choosing \(A = 0\) would make \(u \equiv 0\) so we must force \(\sin \lambda\) to be zero i.e. choose \(\lambda = nπ\) where \(n\) is a positive integer.
Thus, at this stage \((4)\) becomes
\(\qquad u = A \cos nπx(Ce^{nπy} + De^{-nπy})\)
\(     \qquad = \cos nπx(Ee^{nπy} + F e^{−nπy})\) \[(5)\]
